ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: good
2 hours (more for presentation and paper etc)

The homework assignments for this course (each only worth 3% of our grade) take 4-5 hours to complete, which is much too long. The comprehensive quizzes also take a long time to study for - perhaps about 6-7 hours. The final group presentation only took about 3-4 hours because it is a group project.
I probably spent 2 hours per week working outside the classroom for this course. There was homework due every week for this class.
4 hours
4 hours
6-8 hours
The hours I spent ranged from 0-10+ depending on what was due. I would spend many hours on homework assignments.
When a homework assignment or project was due, probably 6-8 hours/week
5 hr per homework assignment (more if you have trouble picking up SAS quickly. )the homework is lengthy but not difficult.
3 hours
3hr
2-10 hours. More like 10hrs time if there was homework assigned. I'm not great at SAS.
10-15 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: I think this class should be an elective; I haven't heard of many HCM students using SAS in the workforce, so having this class along with biostats was not only repetitive but unfortunately not pertinent to what I want to do in the future. I don't think at the graduate level we should be forced to take non-accreditation required courses; from talking to friends in other MPH programs, they do not take a similar course. It's a waste of the students and instructors' time for us to do the bare minimum to get through the class - Chen is a great professor and should have students that care about the material.
This course is really not relevant to people who do not want to do research. Very repetitive of Biostats 2.
good

strengths: Professor Chen was very sweet and knowledgeable, and made very sincere efforts to engage students.weakness: This is a mandatory course for HPM, and I do not necessarily see the necessity of taking it. This is not any fault of the instructor, I just think our time may have been better spent in an economics or health policy class. I also did not find the lab sections to be particularly helpful or productive

This class is misaligned with Stats 2. There was significant overlap with Stats and busy work which was not appreciated. Additionally, management students WILL NOT be using SAS in their professional careers. Spending hours a week on SAS really grated on the HCM cohort and some just elected to not do the homework. Learning research methods in excel or stata would be much more appropriate for policy and management. This a professional school and we should be learning skills that will serve us in our professional careers.

Professor is a great guy, but the class itself is unnecessary. We already took Biostats I, we were in Biostats II at the same time, and we are all thoroughly fed up with SAS -- which none of us will ever use outside of this program.Useful understanding of different research methodologies, but not sure that merits an entire course.Workload was manageable, but some assignments were extremely ambiguous and it was difficult to get clarification from professor or TAs.

This course overlaps heavily with Biostatistics and HCM students many only need to take either this course OR biostatistics. There was a lot of redundant material.A HUGE issue that should have been foreseen before the semester started is classroom capacity. If administrators knew that all health policy and management students are required to take this course, then they should have assigned classrooms that can actually accommodate all of us. There should have also been 2 lab sessions from the beginning. The computer labs at 47 College are much too small to hold all of us.
This class did overlap with biostats 2 at times but I believe I left this class with a much better understanding how to apply statistical methods to public health research.

I believe this class could be very helpful in providing an overview of statistic topics that may be useful (rather than take Biostats 2). I the PowerPoint presentations/slides for both lecture and lab were more clear, better organized, easier to follow, etc it would make a huge difference. Especially for lab, because I didn't think it would help us do our homework. If lab presentations were organized like biostats labs, and HW followed the labs, it would make a huge difference.
This course was difficult because the content moved faster than the content in biostats. We were learning some of the same things, but at different times.

This class has too much work. Near weekly p-sets, quizzes, group project, and final project. I think the group project could function as the capstone to the course. Dr. Chen is a very nice guy. He is extremely responsive via email or will meet with you in person to discuss things you don't understand. Sometimes it takes the third or fourth time of him explaining something for it to make sense, though. His teaching and powerpoint slides, as well as the ease of navigating this course are all lacking. But, if you give 200% and work with Dr. Chen, you can get something out of it. Generally though, I think this class repeats a lot of material from Epi1 and Biostats2, so I'm not sure why it's required.

I don't see the purpose of management students of taking this course AND biostats.Professor Chen is awesome but this class was focused too heavily on SAS which is essentially an outdated program not utilized or recognized by Many large firms.If this class was truly a methods class, it should be focused on providing skills with greater utility in the professional world such as data analysis (NOT coding to get data) and excel.
Strength- Prof.Chen's commitmentWeakness- Too many assignments

I think that this course covers important material, but I think that the structure could be improved. It was definitely hard to get thrown into regression when we hadn't even touched upon it in biostats yet. What I will say, though, is while I definitely would have said (all semester) that biostatistics taught me far more than Methods and in a more understandable way, I realized in studying for the biostats final that this was not actually the case. I felt that I was much more confident with the material that I had learned in Methods for the biostats exam.

I wanted to like this class, but the other students and one of the TA's made it nearly impossible. Many of the management students had strong negative feelings for the class that were made known at every possible opportunity. As a policy student, genuinely interested in research, I would have preferred that this not be required for them. Material was interesting and necessary, in my opinion, but the delivery was at times was lacking.
Strength- comprehensiveWeakness- Needs to be more relevant to healthcare management students
Course could be better structured.
I ended up learning a lot, but the start of the semester was a rocky start where I wasn't sure what the point was for a lot of what we were learning.
- quizzes and homework are very difficult- enjoyed the group project

It was difficult to follow the information as we were a few weeks behind in biostats and didn't have the statistical or SAS knowledge to complete the homework assignments.Feedback/more time to decide on questions for the group assignment would have been nice and made it easier at the end during the data analysis stage.Lecture materials could have been more clear and concise.
Strengths: Useful for students interested in survey design and regression analysisWeaknesses: The class was poorly taught

although, lectures can be hard to follow because they might be a bit disoriented - after doing the homework (which is actual application), you'll better understand the method used and it will become clear in the end.the process will probably be something like this:1) 'what the hell is going on' thoughts in class2) struggle during hw3) struggle some more4) then 'aha! i've got it!' moments will follow.i can say that i've learned more in this class regarding SAS than any other i have taken in my first year so this course must be doing something right!

Strengths: very responsive, friendly and helpful professor and TAs. The labs helped with accomplishing the assignments and this class complemented BIS505b really well.Weaknesses: poor logistics (space/timing issues of course) that were beyond the professor's control but were pretty distracting at times.

First of all the course started on the wrong foot because the lab was organized poorly. If 50 students are enrolled for the course, there will not be enough computers for students. So administrators and profs need to get that right.Otherwise, there was a lack of continuity in the course. It was unclear to many of my fellow colleagues the value of the material and how it was relevant to their studies, or future professions. I believe this could be remedied by a few minutes during every class touching on this topic.Finally, the slides were not comprehensive enough given the difficulty of the topic. I frequently used Dr. Ciarleglio's slides to supplement the regression analysis material.
This was a required course. I would not have taken it otherwise.
Weakness - Not pertinent to most student's career interests, thus the focus of the course should have been less lab based and more overarching.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Xi Chen  Great guy. Hope he can teach in a more interesting and engaging way.
Instructor: Xi Chen  Great instructor!

Instructor: Xi Chen  Chen really cares about the material and students; it's not his fault that the material did not appeal to the students. He really wanted everyone to do well and did everything in his power to make that happen.
Instructor: Xi Chen  Prof Chen was very friendly and willing to help. Wanted to make sure we understood the material.
Instructor: Xi Chen  good
Instructor: Xi Chen  Xi made a large effort to reach out to students. He was a little hard to understand at times, but his slides were overall clear and comprehensive.

Instructor: Xi Chen  Nice guy, helpful and supportive, wants students to do well. Language barrier is a bit of an impediment, and slides would benefit from a thorough review and edit by TAs. Made himself available to students and graded fairly. Group project was a good experience.

Instructor: Xi Chen  Most of us have a really hard time understanding Professor Chen's thick accent. It becomes very frustrating to even grasp the basic material simply because we don't know what he's saying. It has become a motivation to not even attend class. He is very nice, however, and I have found that it is easier to communicate with him via email when I have questions about assignments.
Instructor: Xi Chen  Professor Chen is very enthusiastic about the material and his presentations had really good examples about how the methods have been applied in public health research.
Instructor: Xi Chen  Professor Chen is very friendly, excited about this topic and the work that he does. I believe lectures and labs should be more clear and better organized though.
Instructor: Xi Chen  Professor Chen was very nice and helpful. The lectures were not particularly interesting, but he provided useful feedback.
Instructor: Xi Chen  Great teacher. Hard worker. Always available outside office hours too

Instructor: Xi Chen  I think that Xi will become a great professor, but he still has to work on engaging a class. I also think that while he tries to explain things in simple terms, he takes a lot for granted on the part of the students. For a student who really does not get econometrics, class could be hard to follow I'm sure. I will say that I did attend class and did not usually find it difficult to follow, but I think I am in the minority.

Instructor: Xi Chen  Dr. Chen was so available to students and very passionate about the subject. He is knowledgable about research, however the issue of class lecture was troubling, both because we were in a space way too small for lab and our lecture time was cut to just over an hour per week.
Instructor: Xi Chen  Very sweet, but difficult to understand.
Instructor: Xi Chen  Good instructor, could have better slides.

Instructor: Xi Chen  Wonderful professor in terms of accessibility and answering questions when approached outside of class. In class though, often difficult to decipher the significance of what we were being taught.
Instructor: Xi Chen  - good professor and slides, but someone difficult to understand lectures
Instructor: Xi Chen  Passionate and cares about the material. Willing to help during lab and outside of class.

Instructor: Xi Chen  Strengths: Friendly, seemed genuinely interested in seeing students succeed in the course, and did his best to make himself available for students outside of his regular office hours. Loves the course material.Weaknesses: Language barrier made it hard for most students to follow the lecture. Labs were not always well taught.

Instructor: Xi Chen  Prof Chen is very nice and always open to help, as long as you ask. He responds quickly to email, especially if you have specific questions regarding how to approach the homework.

Instructor: Xi Chen  Very accommodating and friendly, very knowledgeable on the subject and willing to give practical examples for what we learn in class, creates projects a practical aspect as well.Better at explaining concepts in smaller settings/during office hours than in large class settings.
Instructor: Xi Chen  Dr. Chen tried to get our feedback and was very responsive and concerned for students' well-being and understanding.
Instructor: Xi Chen  Very helpful and approachable professor, as well as generous with his time.

Instructor: Xi Chen  There is a language barrier.He is very nice and knowledgable. The syllabus was very organized, and he stayed on schedule. He is a poor teacher. His talents should be used by YSPH in other capacities.
Instructor: Xi Chen  Great person to get one on one feedback, though not the most effective lecturer

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Instructor: Hongyu Zhang  Enthusiastic and knowledgable.

Instructor: Hongyu Zhang  Enthusiastic, knowledgeable, and helpful. Would help if TAs reviewed the slides together before lab, as occasionally there was incorrect or misleading material (same goes for homework assignments)

Instructor: Hongyu Zhang  I am choosing to evaluate Karen because I wanted to mention a concern that I had for much of the semester which was that Karen really often treated students in a sort of disrespectful way. I think it was hard for her to understand what it was like for students to not understand stats or SAS or other course material, and she would make some students feel dumb which I think is completely inappropriate.
Instructor: Hongyu Zhang  Really helpful with the homework.
Instructor: Hongyu Zhang  Very approachable and helpful!
Instructor: Hongyu Zhang  Both TFs were great!
Instructor: Hongyu Zhang  Strengths: Very capable TA who was willing to help students.Weaknesses: Difficult for students to understand her at times due to the language barrier

Instructor: Hongyu Zhang  karen is very smart, while some may be intimidated by this& also make her a bit hard to approach. if you can keep up with the work a bit or at least comprehend to a certain extent something or another regarding SAS - she is helpful when it comes to confusion on how to correctly interpret results.overall, i found her very helpful when necessary - especially since i prefer direct answers and minimal hand holding
Instructor: Hongyu Zhang  Responds quickly and thoroughly to questions in person and via email. Good understanding of the material she's teaching.
Instructor: Hongyu Zhang  Karen has a great handle on the knowledge, so much so that we would get more information than needed for our level of comprehension!
Instructor: Shefali Kumar  So helpful! Really gota lot out of her office hours.
Instructor: Shefali Kumar  good
Instructor: Shefali Kumar  Shefali was very accessible, and her office hours were usually extremely helpful and elucidating

Instructor: Shefali Kumar  Shefali is usually available to answer our questions about homework and group assignments. Both her and Hongyu have helped to fill the gaps in our knowledge when we can't understand Professor Chen's lectures.

Instructor: Shefali Kumar  Shefali - really understands the material and is great to work withKaren - she also understands the material but is not sensitive when providing feedback. It's like she is talking down to usand almost makes us feel bad that we don't understand the material.
Instructor: Shefali Kumar  Shefali was very helpful and nice. I visited her office hours and she was very patient and helped me multiple times.
Instructor: Shefali Kumar  Awesome TAs
Instructor: Shefali Kumar  great job!
Instructor: Shefali Kumar  Extremely helpful!

Instructor: Shefali Kumar  Karen-There is a language barrier. I went to her TA hours a couple of times. I felt she was not patient with me.Terrible at lab presentations.I hired a tutor.Shefali-I did not go to her office hours on Thursday due to conflict in schedule.Terrible at lab presentations. She read the slides. I know how to read.
Instructor: Shefali Kumar  Shefali is amazing. Everything I learned from Methods, I learned from her.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: good

This course will teach you about survey design, data collection, and subsequent analysis.I would not recommend this class because I felt that between 5 homework's 2 quizzes a group project and an individual paper there was just way too much work. I think at least one of these assignments could have been eliminated, or that the final paper could be shortened to be a one page brief.
Not too taxing, but a bit redundant. Some useful information but not necessarily worth an entire semester-long class. Decent group project, and professor is helpful and accessible.

This course overlapped too much with Biostatistics and I thought it was not necessary especially for HCM students. I heard that this is already going to start for next year's students, but HCM students should be able to choose either this OR biostatistics. I can't say I gained much value from this course with Professor Chen, unfortunately. I would certainly not recommend this course to other students if they are already taking another SAS-heavy course like biostatistics.
I wouldn't recommend this course to HCM students although it is required. The content is similar to biostats II, but there is much more SAS work.
Useful course. I would recommend it
I think that Methods is interesting. I think the field of econometrics can be interesting. I just think the course could be improved. I probably would not recommend it to a fellow student as is.

This course is fantastic if you like research. Please stop making management students take this course because they ruin it for the rest of us. Lab assignments were at times unnecessarily long given the percent of grade.
Understanding the basics of research methods was useful. However the course quickly became irrelevant to my interests.
Recommend it.
- goes alongside biostats II, but much more difficult
It's required for HCM/Policy. If you can get out of it, get out of it. It is a lot of work and there is a lot of overlap with BioStats. Do not see the potential use of this class in my future career.

The course may not be useful for all policy students and YSPH should criticallyevaluate whether another course is necessary for policy students who will not be doing quantitative statistics or regression.
recommend
Helpful for understanding/conducting research, and a good supplement to BIS505b. Recommended to students with an interest in those areas.
It is a required course with some leadership challenges.
I would not recommend this course.
A requirement, but otherwise would suggest finding a way to exempt from it.
